Random Access Broadcast: Stability and Throughput Analysis

Brooke¬†Shrader,¬† and¬†Anthony¬†Ephremides This work is supported in part by the Office of Naval Research through grant N000140610065 and by the Department of Defense under MURI grant S0176941. Prepared through collaborative participation in the Communications and Networks Consortium sponsored by the U. S. Army Research Laboratory under The Collaborative Technology Alliance Program, Cooperative Agreement DAAD19-01-2-0011. The U. S. Government is authorized to reproduce and distribute reprints for Government purposes notwithstanding any copyright notation thereon. B. Shrader and A. The material in this paper was presented in part at the 2005 International Symposium on Information Theory¬†(ISIT) in Adelaide, Australia.
Abstract

A wireless network in which packets are broadcast to a group of receivers through use of a random access protocol is considered in this work. The relation to previous work on networks of interacting queues is discussed and subsequently, the stability and throughput regions of the system are analyzed and presented. A simple network of two source nodes and two destination nodes is considered first. The broadcast service process is analyzed assuming a channel that allows for packet capture and multipacket reception. In this small network, the stability and throughput regions are observed to coincide. The same problem for a network with NùëÅN sources and MùëÄM destinations is considered next. The channel model is simplified in that multipacket reception is no longer permitted. Bounds on the stability region are developed using the concept of stability rank and the throughput region of the system is compared to the bounds. Our results show that as the number of destination nodes increases, the stability and throughput regions diminish. Additionally, a previous conjecture that the stability and throughput regions coincide for a network of arbitrarily many sources is supported for a broadcast scenario by the results presented in this work.

Index Terms:
wireless broadcast, random access, ALOHA, queueing, stability, throughput, multipacket reception

I Introduction

The stability and throughput of finite-user random access systems for unicast transmission have been studied extensively. The throughput analysis is included in some of Abramson‚Äôs early work on the topic [1], while the stability problem was first introduced by Tsybakov and Mikhailov [2]. The finite-user stability problem proves to be much more difficult than the throughput problem, and as such, the history of the stability problem is more rich and interesting. In [2], sufficient conditions for ergodicity were found using the transition probabilities of the Markov chain corresponding to queue lengths. Later work [3] described the use of stochastic dominance as a means of characterizing the stability region. Additionally, stability conditions based on the joint queue statistics were provided in [4]. Despite these and other attempts, the stability region for arbitrarily many sources NùëÅN remains unsolved. In [5] the concept of stability rank was introduced and provided the tightest known bounds to the stability region for NùëÅN sources. The exact stability region for NùëÅN sources and an arrival process which is correlated among the sources was obtained in [6].

Most works, including all of those mentioned above, study random access under the collision channel model, in which transmission by more than one source results in failed reception of all packets. Some recent works have incorporated the probabilistic nature of reception and the possibility of multipacket reception (MPR) into the channel model. The stability of infinite-user random access with MPR was first examined in [7]. More recently, the finite-user problem was examined in [8] and it was shown that the possibility of MPR results in an increase in the stable throughput of the system. The benefit to stability was so dramatic that for channels with sufficiently strong reception capabilities, random access was shown to outperform time division multiple access (TDMA) schemes. This result provides motivation for a renewed interest in random access.

In this correspondence we introduce multiple destination nodes and broadcast transmission into the network and study the resulting stability and throughput performance of random access. The introduction of multiple destinations is a necessary first step in understanding the behavior of ad hoc and multihop networks, where random access presents an advantage over TDMA due to its distributed nature. In particular, we analyze the performance of a random access broadcast system in which a source node sends a common packet to all destination nodes. Broadcast transmission is useful for control of the network (ie, initialization, route discovery, timing synchronization) and for a number of applications.

II Model and formulation

Consider a system ùíÆùíÆ{\cal S} consisting of NùëÅN source nodes, s1,s2,‚Ä¶,sNsubscriptùë†1subscriptùë†2‚Ä¶subscriptùë†ùëÅs_{1},s_{2},\ldots,s_{N}, and MùëÄM destination nodes d(1),d(2),‚Ä¶,d(M)superscriptùëë1superscriptùëë2‚Ä¶superscriptùëëùëÄd^{(1)},d^{(2)},\ldots,d^{(M)}. Packets arrive to snsubscriptùë†ùëõs_{n} according to a Bernoulli process with rate ŒªnsubscriptùúÜùëõ\lambda_{n}, n=1,2,‚Ä¶,Nùëõ12‚Ä¶ùëÅn=1,2,\ldots,N packets per slot. The arrival process is independent from source to source and independent, identically distributed (i.i.d) over slots. Packets that are not immediately transmitted are stored in an infinite buffer maintained at each source. All source nodes compete in a random fashion for access to the channel in order to transmit a packet of information to all destination nodes. When source nùëõn has a packet to transmit, it does so with probability pnsubscriptùëùùëõp_{n} in the first available slot. This scenario is depicted in Fig.1. Each packet is intended for all MùëÄM destinations. We assume that instantaneous and error-free acknowledgements (ACKs) are sent from the destinations and that each source-destination pair has a dedicated channel for ACKs. If the source has not yet received an ACK from all MùëÄM destinations, the packet is retransmitted. This policy of relentless retransmissions is assumed throughout the present work. We note that this policy is sub-optimal in terms of stable throughput. For instance, in the case of a single destination M=1ùëÄ1M=1, collision resolution algorithms such as the one in [9] have been shown to provide a higher stable throughput in the infinite-user case. We choose to focus our attention on random access with retransmissions as a first, non-trivial step in investigating the stability of random access broadcast.

The vector of queue lengths forms an NùëÅN-dimensional, irreducible, aperiodic Markov chain ùêê‚Äã(k)=(Q1‚Äã(k),Q2‚Äã(k),‚Ä¶,QN‚Äã(k))ùêêùëòsubscriptùëÑ1ùëòsubscriptùëÑ2ùëò‚Ä¶subscriptùëÑùëÅùëò\mathbf{Q}(k)=(Q_{1}(k),Q_{2}(k),\ldots,Q_{N}(k)). The system is stable if, for ùê±‚àà‚ÑïNùê±superscript‚ÑïùëÅ\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{N}^{N}

For our Markov chain ùêê‚Äã(k)ùêêùëò\mathbf{Q}(k), stability is equivalent to positive recurrence of the Markov chain. We define the stability region of the system is the set of all arrival rates (Œª1,Œª2,‚Ä¶,ŒªN)subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúÜ2‚Ä¶subscriptùúÜùëÅ(\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},\ldots,\lambda_{N}) for which there exists a set of transmission probabilities (p1,p2,‚Ä¶,pN)subscriptùëù1subscriptùëù2‚Ä¶subscriptùëùùëÅ(p_{1},p_{2},\ldots,p_{N}) such that the system is stable. A primary tool used in our work is Loynes‚Äô result [10], which tells us that if An‚Äã(k)subscriptùê¥ùëõùëòA_{n}(k) and Bn‚Äã(k)subscriptùêµùëõùëòB_{n}(k) are nonnegative, finite, and strictly stationary, then source nùëõn is stable if and only if Œªn<ŒºnsubscriptùúÜùëõsubscriptùúáùëõ\lambda_{n}<\mu_{n}.

II-B Dominant systems

In the original system ùíÆùíÆ{\cal S}, we cannot easily write down the average service rate Œºnsubscriptùúáùëõ\mu_{n} of a source because the service rate varies depending on whether the other sources are empty or backlogged. Instead, we introduce a dominant system ùíÆ[1]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]1{\cal S}^{[1]} which behaves exactly like system ùíÆùíÆ{\cal S} except that all NùëÅN sources continue to transmit ‚Äúdummy‚Äù packets when empty. The dummy packets do not affect the information-carrying ability of the source, but their transmission results in a decoupling of the queues. In the dominant system ùíÆ[1]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]1{\cal S}^{[1]}, all sources behave as if they are backlogged, the probability of interference from other sources is known according to the pnsubscriptùëùùëõp_{n} values, and we can easily write down the service rates Œºn[1]superscriptsubscriptùúáùëõdelimited-[]1\mu_{n}^{[1]}. Let Qn[1]superscriptsubscriptùëÑùëõdelimited-[]1Q_{n}^{[1]} denote the length of the queue at source nùëõn in system ùíÆ[1]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]1{\cal S}^{[1]}. It can be shown [2] that if Œºn[1]‚â§Œºnsuperscriptsubscriptùúáùëõdelimited-[]1subscriptùúáùëõ\mu_{n}^{[1]}\leq\mu_{n} then ‚àÄx‚àà‚Ñïfor-allùë•‚Ñï\forall x\in\mathbb{N},

Pr‚Äã{Qn[1]>x}‚â•Pr‚Äã{Qn>x}.PrsuperscriptsubscriptùëÑùëõdelimited-[]1ùë•PrsubscriptùëÑùëõùë•\mbox{Pr}\{Q_{n}^{[1]}>x\}\geq\mbox{Pr}\{Q_{n}>x\}.

In other words, the length of the queue in ùíÆ[1]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]1{\cal S}^{[1]} is never shorter than in ùíÆùíÆ{\cal S}. So if we find the conditions for stability in ùíÆ[1]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]1{\cal S}^{[1]}, then stability in ùíÆùíÆ{\cal S} is implied. Thus, stability in the dominant system is a sufficient condition for stability in the original system.

II-C Throughput Region

We define the throughput region of the system as the stability region under the assumption that all sources are always backlogged. As such, we ignore the burstiness of the arrival process. The throughput region of the system ùíÆùíÆ{\cal S} is equivalent to the stability region of the dominant system ùíÆ[1]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]1{\cal S}^{[1]}. As we noted above, stability in the dominant system ùíÆ[1]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]1{\cal S}^{[1]} implies stability in the original system ùíÆùíÆ{\cal S}, so the throughput region of the system provides an inner bound to the stability region. It has been conjectured (see [11] and references therein) that the stability region and the throughput region coincide for NùëÅN sources and a single destination. This conjecture suggests that the zero state Qn=0subscriptùëÑùëõ0Q_{n}=0 plays no role in determining the ergodicity of the Markov chain ùêê‚Äã(k)ùêêùëò\mathbf{Q}(k). A proof of this conjecture has not been found, and is hindered by the fact that the stability region for NùëÅN sources has not been found.

After simplification, the backlogged service rates can be expressed as

Œºn‚Äãb=pn‚Äãœïn‚ÄãœÉn‚Äã(œïn+œÉn‚àíœÑn)(œïn+œÉn)‚Äã(œïn+œÉn‚àíœÑn)‚àíœïn‚ÄãœÉn.subscriptùúáùëõùëèsubscriptùëùùëõsubscriptitalic-œïùëõsubscriptùúéùëõsubscriptitalic-œïùëõsubscriptùúéùëõsubscriptùúèùëõsubscriptitalic-œïùëõsubscriptùúéùëõsubscriptitalic-œïùëõsubscriptùúéùëõsubscriptùúèùëõsubscriptitalic-œïùëõsubscriptùúéùëõ\mu_{nb}=\frac{p_{n}\phi_{n}\sigma_{n}(\phi_{n}+\sigma_{n}-\tau_{n})}{(\phi_{n}+\sigma_{n})(\phi_{n}+\sigma_{n}-\tau_{n})-\phi_{n}\sigma_{n}}. (7)

We let Œº1‚Äãesubscriptùúá1ùëí\mu_{1e} denote the service rate of s1subscriptùë†1s_{1} when s2subscriptùë†2s_{2} is empty and similarly, Œº2‚Äãesubscriptùúá2ùëí\mu_{2e} is the service rate of s2subscriptùë†2s_{2} when s1subscriptùë†1s_{1} is empty. These service rates can be found directly from the backlogged service rates as

Œº1‚Äãe=.Œº1‚Äãb|p2=0,Œº2‚Äãe=.Œº2‚Äãb|p1=0.\mu_{1e}=\Bigl{.}\mu_{1b}\Bigr{|}_{p_{2}=0},\quad\mu_{2e}=\Bigl{.}\mu_{2b}\Bigr{|}_{p_{1}=0}. (8)

III-B Stability and throughput regions

We apply the approach introduced in [3] to find the stability region for NùëÅN=2 and MùëÄM=2. For fixed (p1,p2)subscriptùëù1subscriptùëù2(p_{1},p_{2}) the following theorem provides the condition for stability.

Theorem 1

For a network with N=2ùëÅ2N=2 sources, M=2ùëÄ2M=2 destinations, fixed (p1,p2)subscriptùëù1subscriptùëù2(p_{1},p_{2}) and Œºn‚Äãb‚â§Œºn‚Äãe,n=1,2formulae-sequencesubscriptùúáùëõùëèsubscriptùúáùëõùëíùëõ12\mu_{nb}\leq\mu_{ne},n=1,2, a necessary and sufficient condition for stability is that the arrival rates lie within the union of the following two regions.

Œª1<Œª2Œº2‚Äãb‚ÄãŒº1‚Äãb+(1‚àíŒª2Œº2‚Äãb)‚ÄãŒº1‚Äãe,Œª2<Œº2‚Äãb.formulae-sequencesubscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúÜ2subscriptùúá2ùëèsubscriptùúá1ùëè1subscriptùúÜ2subscriptùúá2ùëèsubscriptùúá1ùëísubscriptùúÜ2subscriptùúá2ùëè\lambda_{1}<\frac{\lambda_{2}}{\mu_{2b}}\mu_{1b}+\left(1-\frac{\lambda_{2}}{\mu_{2b}}\right)\mu_{1e},\quad\lambda_{2}<\mu_{2b}. (9)
Œª1<Œº1‚Äãb,Œª2<Œª1Œº1‚Äãb‚ÄãŒº2‚Äãb+(1‚àíŒª1Œº1‚Äãb)‚ÄãŒº2‚Äãe.formulae-sequencesubscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúá1ùëèsubscriptùúÜ2subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúá1ùëèsubscriptùúá2ùëè1subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúá1ùëèsubscriptùúá2ùëí\lambda_{1}<\mu_{1b},\quad\lambda_{2}<\frac{\lambda_{1}}{\mu_{1b}}\mu_{2b}+\left(1-\frac{\lambda_{1}}{\mu_{1b}}\right)\mu_{2e}. (10)

This theorem is a generalization of the result in [3] and the proof follows the one provided in that work. To obtain the stability region over all (p1,p2)subscriptùëù1subscriptùëù2(p_{1},p_{2}) we formulate a constrained optimization problem in which we fix Œª1subscriptùúÜ1\lambda_{1} and maximize Œª2subscriptùúÜ2\lambda_{2} over (p1,p2)subscriptùëù1subscriptùëù2(p_{1},p_{2}) subject to Eqns. 9 and 10 [8].

Analyzing the throughput region of the system is equivalent to examining a single dominant system, ùíÆ[1]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]1{\cal S}^{[1]}, and the corresponding condition for stability over all (p1,p2)subscriptùëù1subscriptùëù2(p_{1},p_{2}). The stability condition for fixed (p1,p2)subscriptùëù1subscriptùëù2(p_{1},p_{2}) is expressed as

Œª1<Œº1‚Äãb,Œª2<Œº2‚Äãb.formulae-sequencesubscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúá1ùëèsubscriptùúÜ2subscriptùúá2ùëè\lambda_{1}<\mu_{1b},\quad\lambda_{2}<\mu_{2b}. (11)

We can find points on the boundary of the throughput region by again fixing the value of Œª1subscriptùúÜ1\lambda_{1} and maximizing Œª2subscriptùúÜ2\lambda_{2} over (p1,p2)subscriptùëù1subscriptùëù2(p_{1},p_{2}) subject to Eqn. 11. The following theorem states that the throughput region coincides with the stability region; a proof is found in the appendix.

Theorem 2

For a random access broadcast system with N=2ùëÅ2N=2 source nodes, M=2ùëÄ2M=2 destination nodes, and service rates as given in (7) and (8), the throughput region is identical to the stability region.

III-C Numerical results

In Fig. 3 we show the stability and throughput regions computed for two different channels with reception probabilities given in Table I. The figure demonstrates that as the probability of capture or MPR increases, the stability region transforms from a strictly concave region to a convex region bounded by straight lines, which agrees with the results in [8] for unicast transmission. These results also demonstrate that for a network with NùëÅN=2 sources and MùëÄM=2 destinations, the broadcast stability and throughput regions coincide, confirming Theorem 2.

IV A network of NùëÅN sources and MùëÄM destinations

IV-A The channel model and service rates

The channel model is now a simplified version of the model presented for the NùëÅN=2, MùëÄM=2 scenario. We assume that whenever two or more sources transmit simultaneously, none of the transmissions are successful. Additionally, we assume that the channel reception probabilities from a source are the same for all destinations, qn|n(1)=qn|n(2)=‚Ä¶=qn|n(M)=qn|nsuperscriptsubscriptùëûconditionalùëõùëõ1superscriptsubscriptùëûconditionalùëõùëõ2‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùëûconditionalùëõùëõùëÄsubscriptùëûconditionalùëõùëõq_{n|n}^{(1)}=q_{n|n}^{(2)}=\ldots=q_{n|n}^{(M)}=q_{n|n}, n=1‚Äã‚Ä¶‚ÄãNùëõ1‚Ä¶ùëÅn=1\ldots N. We refer to the destinations as being indistinguishable in this channel model.

We define the receiver-state variable rnsubscriptùëüùëõr_{n} for each source n=1,2,‚Ä¶,Nùëõ12‚Ä¶ùëÅn=1,2,\ldots,N as the number of destinations that have received the packet that source nùëõn is attempting to transmit, rn‚àà[0,1,‚Ä¶,M‚àí1]subscriptùëüùëõ01‚Ä¶ùëÄ1r_{n}\in[0,1,\ldots,M-1]. We do not allow rnsubscriptùëüùëõr_{n} to take value MùëÄM since as soon as all destinations have received the packet, the source will instantaneously revert back to rn=0subscriptùëüùëõ0r_{n}=0 and either begin serving the next packet in the queue of source nùëõn or become idle if the source is empty. We define the set ‚Ñ¨‚Ñ¨{\cal B} as the set of all sources that are backlogged at the time source nùëõn is attempting to transmit the packet at the front of its queue. Let Œ≤nsubscriptùõΩùëõ\beta_{n} denote that probability that source nùëõn accesses the channel without interference, i.e.,

Œ≤n=pn‚Äã(‚àèl‚àà‚Ñ¨‚àñnpl¬Ø).subscriptùõΩùëõsubscriptùëùùëõsubscriptproductùëô‚Ñ¨ùëõ¬Øsubscriptùëùùëô\beta_{n}=p_{n}\left(\prod_{l\in{\cal B}\setminus n}\overline{p_{l}}\right). (12)

The service process conditioned on rnsubscriptùëüùëõr_{n} can be described by

Pr‚Äã{Bn=1|rn=r}=Œ≤n‚Äãqn|nM‚àír.Prconditional-setsubscriptùêµùëõ1subscriptùëüùëõùëüsubscriptùõΩùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëûconditionalùëõùëõùëÄùëü\mbox{Pr}\{B_{n}=1|r_{n}=r\}=\beta_{n}{q_{n|n}}^{M-r}. (13)

We again develop a Markov chain model for rnsubscriptùëüùëõr_{n} as shown in Fig. 4. In this model, transitions ‚Äúupward‚Äù can occur between all pairs of states, however, transitions ‚Äúdownward‚Äù can only occur between a state and the 00 state. Additionally, each state has self-transitions. Let ùí´ùí´{\cal P} denote the transition matrix for this Markov chain. When source nùëõn accesses the channel without collision, which happens with probability Œ≤nsubscriptùõΩùëõ\beta_{n}, the transition probability matrix will be a matrix ùí´‚àósuperscriptùí´{\cal P^{*}} which depends only on the reception probabilities qn|nsubscriptùëûconditionalùëõùëõq_{n|n}. Otherwise, a self-transition occurs, corresponding to a transition probability matrix equal to the identity matrix ‚Ñê‚Ñê{\cal I}. Thus, we can describe ùí´ùí´{\cal P} as the convex combination of two probability matrices,

ùí´=Œ≤n‚Äãùí´‚àó+(1‚àíŒ≤n)‚Äã‚Ñê.ùí´subscriptùõΩùëõsuperscriptùí´1subscriptùõΩùëõ‚Ñê{\cal P}=\beta_{n}{\cal P^{*}}+(1-\beta_{n}){\cal I}. (14)

Let ùùÖùùÖ\pi be the stationary distribution of ùí´‚àósuperscriptùí´{\cal P^{*}}, ùùÖ=ùùÖ‚Äãùí´‚àóùùÖùùÖsuperscriptùí´\mbox{\boldmath$\pi$}=\mbox{\boldmath$\pi$}{\cal P^{*}}. Clearly ùùÖùùÖ\pi will also be the stationary distribution of ùí´ùí´{\cal P} since ùùÖ‚Äãùí´=Œ≤n‚ÄãùùÖ+(1‚àíŒ≤n)‚ÄãùùÖùùÖùí´subscriptùõΩùëõùùÖ1subscriptùõΩùëõùùÖ\mbox{\boldmath$\pi$}{\cal P}=\beta_{n}\mbox{\boldmath$\pi$}+(1-\beta_{n})\mbox{\boldmath$\pi$}. We can solve for ùùÖùùÖ\pi as follows. Let pi,j‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñùëóp_{i,j}^{*} denote the probability of transition in rnsubscriptùëüùëõr_{n} from iùëñi to jùëój conditioned on snsubscriptùë†ùëõs_{n} accessing the channel without collision. The transition probabilities are given as

In order to satisfy œÄi=‚àëjœÄj‚Äãpi,j‚àósubscriptùúãùëñsubscriptùëósubscriptùúãùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñùëó\pi_{i}=\sum_{j}\pi_{j}p_{i,j}^{*} we have

Once the steady-state probabilities of the receiver Markov chain are found, the average service rate is given as follows.

Œºn=Œ≤n‚Äã‚àëi=0M‚àí1œÄi‚Äãqn|nM‚àíisubscriptùúáùëõsubscriptùõΩùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ0ùëÄ1subscriptùúãùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëûconditionalùëõùëõùëÄùëñ\mu_{n}=\beta_{n}\sum_{i=0}^{M-1}\pi_{i}{q_{n|n}}^{M-i} (18)

We further define

Œ±n=‚àëi=0M‚àí1œÄi‚Äãqn|nM‚àíi.subscriptùõºùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ0ùëÄ1subscriptùúãùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëûconditionalùëõùëõùëÄùëñ\alpha_{n}=\sum_{i=0}^{M-1}\pi_{i}{q_{n|n}}^{M-i}. (19)

Thus the service rate can be represented in simplified form as

Œºn=Œ≤n‚ÄãŒ±n.subscriptùúáùëõsubscriptùõΩùëõsubscriptùõºùëõ\mu_{n}=\beta_{n}\alpha_{n}. (20)

This equation summarizes the natural relation between our broadcast problem and the unicast collision channel problem [5]. The probability that source nùëõn completes transmission of a packet, given by Œºnsubscriptùúáùëõ\mu_{n}, is equal to Œ≤nsubscriptùõΩùëõ\beta_{n}, the probability that the source access the channel without collision, times Œ±nsubscriptùõºùëõ\alpha_{n}, which is the probability that all destinations receive the packet conditioned on collision-free access to the channel. In the unicast collision channel problem, we have qn|n=1subscriptùëûconditionalùëõùëõ1q_{n|n}=1 and Œ±n=1subscriptùõºùëõ1\alpha_{n}=1. Thus for Œ±n=1subscriptùõºùëõ1\alpha_{n}=1 we would expect the stability region for our broadcast problem to coincide with the results in [5] for the unicast collision channel. This is indeed the case as shown in the following section.

We define the empty and backlogged service rates as follows. When ‚Ñ¨‚Ñ¨{\cal B} contains all NùëÅN sources, the broadcast service rate will take its minimum value Œºn‚Äãbsubscriptùúáùëõùëè\mu_{nb} where

Œºn‚Äãb=pn‚Äã(‚àèl‚â†npl¬Ø)‚ÄãŒ±n.subscriptùúáùëõùëèsubscriptùëùùëõsubscriptproductùëôùëõ¬Øsubscriptùëùùëôsubscriptùõºùëõ\mu_{nb}=p_{n}\left(\prod_{l\neq n}\overline{p_{l}}\right)\alpha_{n}. (21)

The maximum value of Œºnsubscriptùúáùëõ\mu_{n} is attained when only source nùëõn is backlogged and all other sources are empty. We denote this service rate by Œºn‚Äãesubscriptùúáùëõùëí\mu_{ne}

Œºn‚Äãe=pn‚ÄãŒ±n.subscriptùúáùëõùëísubscriptùëùùëõsubscriptùõºùëõ\mu_{ne}=p_{n}\alpha_{n}. (22)

In deriving bounds on the stability region, we will take advantage of the form of Œºnsubscriptùúáùëõ\mu_{n} as expressed in Eqn. 20 and the fact that Œºn‚Äãb‚â§Œºn‚â§Œºn‚Äãesubscriptùúáùëõùëèsubscriptùúáùëõsubscriptùúáùëõùëí\mu_{nb}\leq\mu_{n}\leq\mu_{ne}.

Before continuing, we observe the effect of the number of destinations on the stability and throughput regions as shown in Fig. 5. These results are for NùëÅN=2 sources and M=2,5,ùëÄ25M=2,5, and 15 destinations. The results are generated using the approach outlined for NùëÅN=2, MùëÄM=2 with the exception that we use the backlogged and empty service rates for MùëÄM destinations as given in Eqns. 21 and 22. The results demonstrate that as the number of destinations increases, the broadcast stability and throughput regions diminish in size. Additionally, we observe that the stability and throughput regions coincide. This result is not surprising since the proof of Theorem 2 holds for arbitrary MùëÄM with the channel model described above.

IV-B Stability and throughput regions

We follow the methodology outlined in [5] to develop bounds on the broadcast stability region. These results are a generalization of the bounds on the unicast stability region given in [5]. To begin, by the dominant systems argument and Loynes‚Äô result, we can develop loose inner and outer bounds on the stability region. First, if Œªn<Œºn‚ÄãbsubscriptùúÜùëõsubscriptùúáùëõùëè\lambda_{n}<\mu_{nb}, then since Œºn‚Äãb‚â§Œºnsubscriptùúáùëõùëèsubscriptùúáùëõ\mu_{nb}\leq\mu_{n}, queue nùëõn must be stable. Furthermore, if Œªn<Œºn‚ÄãbsubscriptùúÜùëõsubscriptùúáùëõùëè\lambda_{n}<\mu_{nb} for all nùëõn, then the entire system is stable. Likewise, if Œªn>Œºn‚ÄãbsubscriptùúÜùëõsubscriptùúáùëõùëè\lambda_{n}>\mu_{nb} for all nùëõn, then the system is unstable. This follows since Œªn>Œºn‚ÄãbsubscriptùúÜùëõsubscriptùúáùëõùëè\lambda_{n}>\mu_{nb} corresponds to instability of all the queues in dominant system ùíÆ[1]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]1{\cal S}^{[1]}, in which case all of the queues grow to infinity and the dominant system ùíÆ[1]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]1{\cal S}^{[1]} becomes indistinguishable from the original system ùíÆùíÆ{\cal S} [3]. In order to improve upon these loose bounds, we make use of the stability rank of the queues as introduced in [5]. Let ùíÆ[k]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]ùëò{\cal S}^{[k]} denote a dominant system in which sources k,k+1,‚Ä¶,Nùëòùëò1‚Ä¶ùëÅk,k+1,\ldots,N transmit dummy packets when empty while sources 1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí112‚Ä¶ùëò11,2,\ldots,k-1 do not. The proof for the following theorem is the same as in the original [5] with the exception of the constant Œ±nsubscriptùõºùëõ\alpha_{n}.

Theorem 3

Given ùõåùêçsubscriptùõåùêç\lambda_{N} and ùê©ùêçsubscriptùê©ùêç\bf{p_{N}}, we order the indices of the sources so that

Œª1‚Äã(1‚àíp1)Œ±1‚Äãp1‚â§‚Ä¶‚â§ŒªN‚Äã(1‚àípN)Œ±N‚ÄãpN.subscriptùúÜ11subscriptùëù1subscriptùõº1subscriptùëù1‚Ä¶subscriptùúÜùëÅ1subscriptùëùùëÅsubscriptùõºùëÅsubscriptùëùùëÅ\frac{\lambda_{1}(1-p_{1})}{\alpha_{1}p_{1}}\leq\ldots\leq\frac{\lambda_{N}(1-p_{N})}{\alpha_{N}p_{N}}. (23)

Then in system ùíÆùíÆ{\cal S} and any dominant system ùíÆ[k]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]ùëò{\cal S}^{[k]}, if queue iùëñi is stable and j<iùëóùëñj<i, then queue jùëój is also stable.

We can find conditions for the stability of the system through the procedure outlined in [5]. After ordering the sources according to stability rank, we first check for stability of queue 1 in system ùíÆ[1]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]1{\cal S}^{[1]}. If we find that queue 1 is unstable, we can conclude that the entire system is unstable. However, if queue 1 is stable, we proceed by examining queue 2 in system ùíÆ[2]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]2{\cal S}^{[2]}. Queue 1 is known to be stable in ùíÆ[2]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]2{\cal S}^{[2]} due to the stability rank. Given stability of queue 1, we will check whether queue 2 is stable in ùíÆ[2]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]2{\cal S}^{[2]}. The procedure continues in which the stability of queue kùëòk in system ùíÆ[k]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]ùëò{\cal S}^{[k]} is verified assuming that queues 1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí112‚Ä¶ùëò11,2,\ldots,k-1 are all stable in ùíÆ[k]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]ùëò{\cal S}^{[k]}. If we can finally conclude that queue NùëÅN is stable in system ùíÆ[N]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]ùëÅ{\cal S}^{[N]}, then this implies that the original system is stable.

Assuming that sources 1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí112‚Ä¶ùëò11,2,\ldots,k-1 are all stable, we will develop bounds on the average service rate Œºk[k]superscriptsubscriptùúáùëòdelimited-[]ùëò\mu_{k}^{[k]} for source kùëòk in system ùíÆ[k]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]ùëò{\cal S}^{[k]} in order to help determine whether sksubscriptùë†ùëòs_{k} is stable. We can express Œºk[k]superscriptsubscriptùúáùëòdelimited-[]ùëò\mu_{k}^{[k]} as

Œºk[k]=Œ±k‚Äãpk‚ÄãPE[k]‚Äã‚àèj=k+1N(1‚àípj),superscriptsubscriptùúáùëòdelimited-[]ùëòsubscriptùõºùëòsubscriptùëùùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùê∏delimited-[]ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëóùëò1ùëÅ1subscriptùëùùëó\mu_{k}^{[k]}=\alpha_{k}p_{k}P_{E}^{[k]}\prod_{j=k+1}^{N}(1-p_{j}), (24)

where PE[k]superscriptsubscriptùëÉùê∏delimited-[]ùëòP_{E}^{[k]} is the probability that none of the sources 1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí112‚Ä¶ùëò11,2,\ldots,k-1 transmit in the dominant system ùíÆ[k]superscriptùíÆdelimited-[]ùëò{\cal S}^{[k]}. One way to bound Œºk[k]superscriptsubscriptùúáùëòdelimited-[]ùëò\mu_{k}^{[k]} is by bounding PE[k]superscriptsubscriptùëÉùê∏delimited-[]ùëòP_{E}^{[k]} when expressed as

PE[k]=1‚àíP‚Äãr‚Äã{only one of sources¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1¬†transmits}‚àíP‚Äãr‚Äã{more than one of sources¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1¬†transmit}.superscriptsubscriptùëÉùê∏delimited-[]ùëò1ùëÉùëüonly one of sources¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1¬†transmitsùëÉùëümore than one of sources¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1¬†transmitP_{E}^{[k]}=1-Pr\{\mbox{only one of sources $1,2,\ldots,k-1$ transmits}\}\\ -Pr\{\mbox{more than one of sources $1,2,\ldots,k-1$ transmit}\}. (25)

The bounds on Œºk[k]superscriptsubscriptùúáùëòdelimited-[]ùëò\mu_{k}^{[k]} result in the following two theorems.

Theorem 5

Necessary condition. Given an NùëÅN source, MùëÄM destination random access system with ùõåùêçsubscriptùõåùêç\lambda_{N}, ùê©ùêçsubscriptùê©ùêç\bf{p_{N}} and the sources ordered according to the stability rank as in Eqn. 23 a necessary condition for stability of the system is that ‚àÄkfor-allùëò\forall k,

(28)

The proofs for Theorems 4 and 5 are described in the Appendix. We make use of these two theorems to develop bounds on the stability region by fixing the values of Œª1,Œª2,‚Ä¶,ŒªN‚àí1subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúÜ2‚Ä¶subscriptùúÜùëÅ1\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},\ldots,\lambda_{N-1} and numerically optimizing ŒªNsubscriptùúÜùëÅ\lambda_{N} over all ùê©ùêç‚àà[0,1]Nsubscriptùê©ùêçsuperscript01ùëÅ\mathbf{p_{N}}\in[0,1]^{N} subject to the inequalities given in the Theorems.

The throughput region of the network of arbitrary size can be determined exactly using the backlogged service rates in Eqn. 21. Again, we fix Œª1,Œª2,‚Ä¶,ŒªN‚àí1subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúÜ2‚Ä¶subscriptùúÜùëÅ1\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},\ldots,\lambda_{N-1} and maximize ŒªNsubscriptùúÜùëÅ\lambda_{N} over all ùê©ùêçsubscriptùê©ùêç\bf{p_{N}} subject to ŒªN<ŒºN‚ÄãbsubscriptùúÜùëÅsubscriptùúáùëÅùëè\lambda_{N}<\mu_{Nb}.

IV-C Numerical results

A collection of results on stability and throughput for various values of NùëÅN and MùëÄM are shown in Tables II and III. The values in Table II demonstrate the effect of the channel reception probabilities and the number of destinations on the stability and throughput regions. The trends in these results are the same as those observed for a network of NùëÅN=2 sources. In Table III we observe that as the number of sources NùëÅN increases, the stability and throughput regions diminish in size. Furthermore, in all cases, the throughput values fall within the upper and lower bounds on the stability values. As such, these results support the conjecture that the stability and throughput regions coincide. Of special note, the lower bound for stability and the throughput value appear to be equal in many cases. This is not entirely true. In the results shown here, the throughput value is in fact slightly larger than the lower bound on the stability value, but the difference is at most 10‚àí6superscript10610^{-6}.

V Conclusions

In this work we have investigated the information-carrying ability of source nodes which compete for access to a shared channel in order to broadcast messages to a common set of destination nodes. The scenario we consider is relevant to broadcast applications and network discovery and control. We formulated the problem as a network of queues which interact through the shared channel and investigated the stability and throughput regions of the source nodes. Our results strengthen an unproven conjecture that the stability and throughput regions of finite-user random access coincide. We also demonstrate that the throughput and stable throughput regions diminish as the number of source or destination nodes grows. Our intention in this work is to present results relating to the scaling laws for wireless networks, which often show a degradation in throughput as the number of nodes increases. Our results show a similar trend from a multicast stability point of view.

VI Appendix

VI-A Proof of Theorem 2

We show that the boundaries of the stability and throughput regions, given by the results of two constrained optimization problems, are identical. We replace Œª1subscriptùúÜ1\lambda_{1} by xùë•x and Œª2subscriptùúÜ2\lambda_{2} by yùë¶y. Furthermore, we express the backlogged service rates Œºn‚Äãbsubscriptùúáùëõùëè\mu_{nb} in Eqn. 7 as follows.

Œº1‚Äãb=p1‚Äãf1‚Äã(p2),Œº2‚Äãb=p2‚Äãf2‚Äã(p1).formulae-sequencesubscriptùúá1ùëèsubscriptùëù1subscriptùëì1subscriptùëù2subscriptùúá2ùëèsubscriptùëù2subscriptùëì2subscriptùëù1\mu_{1b}=p_{1}f_{1}(p_{2}),\quad\mu_{2b}=p_{2}f_{2}(p_{1}). (29)

The empty service rates can then be expressed as Œº1‚Äãe=p1‚Äãf1‚Äã(0)subscriptùúá1ùëísubscriptùëù1subscriptùëì10\mu_{1e}=p_{1}f_{1}(0) and Œº2‚Äãe=p2‚Äãf2‚Äã(0)subscriptùúá2ùëísubscriptùëù2subscriptùëì20\mu_{2e}=p_{2}f_{2}(0). In these expressions, f1‚Äã(p2)subscriptùëì1subscriptùëù2f_{1}(p_{2}) is functionally independent of p1subscriptùëù1p_{1} and decreasing in p2subscriptùëù2p_{2}, corresponding to Œº1‚Äãb‚â§Œº1‚Äãe‚áîf1‚Äã(p2)‚â§f1‚Äã(0)iffsubscriptùúá1ùëèsubscriptùúá1ùëísubscriptùëì1subscriptùëù2subscriptùëì10\mu_{1b}\leq\mu_{1e}\iff f_{1}(p_{2})\leq f_{1}(0). Similarly, f2‚Äã(p1)subscriptùëì2subscriptùëù1f_{2}(p_{1}) is independent of p2subscriptùëù2p_{2} and decreasing in p1subscriptùëù1p_{1}. With this notation in place, the boundary of the region given in Theorem 1 for fixed (p1,p2)subscriptùëù1subscriptùëù2(p_{1},p_{2}) can be written as follows.

x=p1‚Äãf1‚Äã(0)‚àíy‚Äãp1‚Äã(f1‚Äã(0)‚àíf1‚Äã(p2))p2‚Äãf2‚Äã(p1),0‚â§y‚â§p2‚Äãf2‚Äã(p1)formulae-sequenceùë•subscriptùëù1subscriptùëì10ùë¶subscriptùëù1subscriptùëì10subscriptùëì1subscriptùëù2subscriptùëù2subscriptùëì2subscriptùëù10ùë¶subscriptùëù2subscriptùëì2subscriptùëù1\displaystyle x=p_{1}f_{1}(0)-\frac{yp_{1}\left(f_{1}(0)-f_{1}(p_{2})\right)}{p_{2}f_{2}(p_{1})},\quad 0\leq y\leq p_{2}f_{2}(p_{1}) (30)
y=p2‚Äãf2‚Äã(0)‚àíx‚Äãp2‚Äã(f2‚Äã(0)‚àíf2‚Äã(p1))p1‚Äãf1‚Äã(p2),0‚â§x‚â§p1‚Äãf1‚Äã(p2)formulae-sequenceùë¶subscriptùëù2subscriptùëì20ùë•subscriptùëù2subscriptùëì20subscriptùëì2subscriptùëù1subscriptùëù1subscriptùëì1subscriptùëù20ùë•subscriptùëù1subscriptùëì1subscriptùëù2\displaystyle y=p_{2}f_{2}(0)-\frac{xp_{2}\left(f_{2}(0)-f_{2}(p_{1})\right)}{p_{1}f_{1}(p_{2})},\quad 0\leq x\leq p_{1}f_{1}(p_{2}) (31)

To find the stability region, we should maximize the expressions in (30) and (31) over (p1,p2)subscriptùëù1subscriptùëù2(p_{1},p_{2}) and take the intersection of the regions bounded by the resulting curves. We note that this is not a standard optimization problem because the objective function is piece-wise and non-differentiable at a point in its domain. An example of an analytical solution to this optimization problem is given in [8] for the single destination case.

VI-B Proof of Theorem 4

Our proof follows the one given in [5]. A sufficient condition for stability corresponds to bounding Œºk[k]superscriptsubscriptùúáùëòdelimited-[]ùëò\mu_{k}^{[k]} from below. We obtain two separate lower bounds, Cksubscriptùê∂ùëòC_{k} and Dksubscriptùê∑ùëòD_{k}, and take their maximum to obtain the result. The bound Cksubscriptùê∂ùëòC_{k} is derived through Eqns. 24 and 25. Since sources 1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí112‚Ä¶ùëò11,2,\ldots,k-1 are stable, the following holds.

P‚Äãr‚Äã{success by one of the sources¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1}=‚àëi=1k‚àí1Œªi‚â•(min1‚â§l‚â§k‚Å°Œ±l)‚ÄãP‚Äãr‚Äã{only one of the sources¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1¬†transmits}‚Äã‚àèj=kN(1‚àípj)ùëÉùëüsuccess by one of the sources¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëò1subscriptùúÜùëñsubscript1ùëôùëòsubscriptùõºùëôùëÉùëüonly one of the sources¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1¬†transmitssuperscriptsubscriptproductùëóùëòùëÅ1subscriptùëùùëóPr\{\mbox{success by one of the sources $1,2,\ldots,k-1$}\}=\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}\lambda_{i}\\ \geq\left(\min_{1\leq l\leq k}\alpha_{l}\right)Pr\{\mbox{only one of the sources $1,2,\ldots,k-1$ transmits}\}\prod_{j=k}^{N}(1-p_{j}) (38)

This indicates that

P‚Äãr‚Äã{only one of the sources¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1¬†transmits}‚â§‚àëi=1k‚àí1Œªi(min1‚â§l‚â§k‚Å°Œ±l)‚Äã‚àèj=kN(1‚àípj).ùëÉùëüonly one of the sources¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1¬†transmitssuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëò1subscriptùúÜùëñsubscript1ùëôùëòsubscriptùõºùëôsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëóùëòùëÅ1subscriptùëùùëóPr\{\mbox{only one of the sources $1,2,\ldots,k-1$ transmits}\}\leq\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}\lambda_{i}}{\left(\min\limits_{1\leq l\leq k}\alpha_{l}\right)\prod_{j=k}^{N}(1-p_{j})}. (39)

For the next term in PE[k]superscriptsubscriptùëÉùê∏delimited-[]ùëòP_{E}^{[k]} we have

P‚Äãr‚Äã{a packet from¬†j¬†collides with others from¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1}=P‚Äãr‚Äã{j¬†transmits}‚àíP‚Äãr‚Äã{j¬†transmits & no others from¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1¬†transmit}=pj‚ÄãP‚Äãr‚Äã{j¬†backlogged}‚àíP‚Äãr‚Äã{j¬†transmits & no others transmit}‚àèi=kN(1‚àípi)=pj‚ÄãŒªjŒºj[k]‚àíŒªjŒ±j‚Äã‚àèi=kN(1‚àípi).ùëÉùëüa packet from¬†j¬†collides with others from¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1ùëÉùëüj¬†transmitsùëÉùëüj¬†transmits & no others from¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1¬†transmitsubscriptùëùùëóùëÉùëüj¬†backloggedùëÉùëüj¬†transmits & no others transmitsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñùëòùëÅ1subscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëósubscriptùúÜùëósuperscriptsubscriptùúáùëódelimited-[]ùëòsubscriptùúÜùëósubscriptùõºùëósuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñùëòùëÅ1subscriptùëùùëñPr\{\mbox{a packet from $j$ collides with others from $1,2,\ldots,k-1$}\}\\ =Pr\{\mbox{$j$ transmits}\}-Pr\{\mbox{$j$ transmits \& no others from $1,2,\ldots,k-1$ transmit}\}\\ =p_{j}Pr\{\mbox{$j$ backlogged}\}-\frac{Pr\{\mbox{$j$ transmits \& no others transmit}\}}{\prod_{i=k}^{N}(1-p_{i})}\\ =p_{j}\frac{\lambda_{j}}{\mu_{j}^{[k]}}-\frac{\lambda_{j}}{\alpha_{j}\prod_{i=k}^{N}(1-p_{i})}. (40)

We also make use of the result shown in [3] that for j<kùëóùëòj<k, Œºj[j]‚â§Œºj[k]superscriptsubscriptùúáùëódelimited-[]ùëósuperscriptsubscriptùúáùëódelimited-[]ùëò\mu_{j}^{[j]}\leq\mu_{j}^{[k]}. Thus, the second term in PE[k]superscriptsubscriptùëÉùê∏delimited-[]ùëòP_{E}^{[k]} is upper bounded as follows.

P‚Äãr‚Äã{more than one of the sources¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1¬†transmits}‚â§12‚Äã‚àëj=1k‚àí1(pj‚ÄãŒªjŒºj[j]‚àíŒªjŒ±j‚Äã‚àèi=kN(1‚àípi))ùëÉùëümore than one of the sources¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1¬†transmits12superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëò1subscriptùëùùëósubscriptùúÜùëósuperscriptsubscriptùúáùëódelimited-[]ùëósubscriptùúÜùëósubscriptùõºùëósuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñùëòùëÅ1subscriptùëùùëñPr\{\mbox{more than one of the sources $1,2,\ldots,k-1$ transmits}\}\leq\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^{k-1}\left(p_{j}\frac{\lambda_{j}}{\mu_{j}^{[j]}}-\frac{\lambda_{j}}{\alpha_{j}\prod_{i=k}^{N}(1-p_{i})}\right) (41)

By combining Eqns. 25, 39, and 41 we obtain the lower bound

PE[k]‚â•1‚àí‚àëi=1k‚àí1Œªi(min1‚â§l‚â§k‚Å°Œ±l)‚Äã‚àèj=kN(1‚àípj)‚àí12‚Äã‚àëj=1k‚àí1(pj‚ÄãŒªjŒºj[j]‚àíŒªjŒ±j‚Äã‚àèi=kN(1‚àípi)).superscriptsubscriptùëÉùê∏delimited-[]ùëò1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëò1subscriptùúÜùëñsubscript1ùëôùëòsubscriptùõºùëôsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëóùëòùëÅ1subscriptùëùùëó12superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëò1subscriptùëùùëósubscriptùúÜùëósuperscriptsubscriptùúáùëódelimited-[]ùëósubscriptùúÜùëósubscriptùõºùëósuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñùëòùëÅ1subscriptùëùùëñP_{E}^{[k]}\geq 1-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}\lambda_{i}}{\left(\min\limits_{1\leq l\leq k}\alpha_{l}\right)\prod_{j=k}^{N}(1-p_{j})}-\frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^{k-1}\left(p_{j}\frac{\lambda_{j}}{\mu_{j}^{[j]}}-\frac{\lambda_{j}}{\alpha_{j}\prod_{i=k}^{N}(1-p_{i})}\right). (42)

Together with Eqn. 24, this provides Cksubscriptùê∂ùëòC_{k}, our first lower bound on Œºk[k]superscriptsubscriptùúáùëòdelimited-[]ùëò\mu_{k}^{[k]}.

The other lower bound on Œºk[k]superscriptsubscriptùúáùëòdelimited-[]ùëò\mu_{k}^{[k]} is derived using an approach from [3]. We have adapted it for the broadcast problem below and refer to it as Dksubscriptùê∑ùëòD_{k}.

Œºk[k]‚â•Œ±k‚Äãpk1‚àípk‚ÄãP‚Äãr‚Äã{no other source transmits}+Œ±k‚Äãpk1‚àípk‚ÄãP‚Äãr‚Äã{one of the first¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1¬†sources transmits but is empty}=Œ±k‚Äãpk1‚àípk‚Äã‚àèj=1N(1‚àípj)‚Äã(1+‚àëi=1k‚àí1(1‚àíŒªiŒºi[i])‚Äãpi1‚àípi)=Dk.superscriptsubscriptùúáùëòdelimited-[]ùëòsubscriptùõºùëòsubscriptùëùùëò1subscriptùëùùëòùëÉùëüno other source transmitssubscriptùõºùëòsubscriptùëùùëò1subscriptùëùùëòùëÉùëüone of the first¬†1,2,‚Ä¶,k‚àí1¬†sources transmits but is emptysubscriptùõºùëòsubscriptùëùùëò1subscriptùëùùëòsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëó1ùëÅ1subscriptùëùùëó1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëò11subscriptùúÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúáùëñdelimited-[]ùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1subscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùê∑ùëò\mu_{k}^{[k]}\geq\frac{\alpha_{k}p_{k}}{1-p_{k}}Pr\{\mbox{no other source transmits}\}\\ +\frac{\alpha_{k}p_{k}}{1-p_{k}}Pr\{\mbox{one of the first $1,2,\ldots,k-1$ sources transmits but is empty}\}\\ =\frac{\alpha_{k}p_{k}}{1-p_{k}}\prod_{j=1}^{N}(1-p_{j})\left(1+\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}\left(1-\frac{\lambda_{i}}{\mu_{i}^{[i]}}\right)\frac{p_{i}}{1-p_{i}}\right)=D_{k}. (43)

Note that we can express the exact value of Œº1[1]superscriptsubscriptùúá1delimited-[]1\mu_{1}^{[1]} as Œº1[1]=Œ±1‚Äãp1‚Äã‚àèj=2N(1‚àípj)superscriptsubscriptùúá1delimited-[]1subscriptùõº1subscriptùëù1superscriptsubscriptproductùëó2ùëÅ1subscriptùëùùëó\mu_{1}^{[1]}=\alpha_{1}p_{1}\prod_{j=2}^{N}(1-p_{j}). By beginning with B1=Œº1[1]subscriptùêµ1superscriptsubscriptùúá1delimited-[]1B_{1}=\mu_{1}^{[1]} we can iterate through kùëòk values 2,‚Ä¶,N2‚Ä¶ùëÅ2,\ldots,N to obtain the result.

The proof of Theorem 5 develops upper bounds on Œºk[k]superscriptsubscriptùúáùëòdelimited-[]ùëò\mu_{k}^{[k]} and thus on PE[k]superscriptsubscriptùëÉùê∏delimited-[]ùëòP_{E}^{[k]}. The technique is similar to the one outlined above in finding Cksubscriptùê∂ùëòC_{k}.
